Package sprouts

Interface Var<T extends @Nullable java.lang.Object>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - The type of the wrapped item.
    All Superinterfaces:
    Observable, Val<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractVariable, PropertyLens
    public interface Var<T extends @Nullable java.lang.Object>
extends Val<T>
    A mutable wrapper for an item which can be observed for changes using Actions registered through the onChange(Channel, Action) method, where the Channel is used to distinguish between changes from different sources (usually application layers like the view model or the view).

    The Channel constant passed to onChange(Channel, Action) ensures that the corresponding Action callback is only invoked when the Val.fireChange(Channel) method or the set(Channel, Object) method is invoked with the same Channel. Usually you will use the From constants to distinguish between important application layers using the From.VIEW_MODEL or From.VIEW channels.

    Note that set(Object) method defaults to the From.VIEW_MODEL channel, which is intended to be used for state changes as part of your core business logic.

    So for example if you have a Var which represents the username of a form, then inside your UI you can register a callback using onChange(Channel, Action) using the channel From.VIEW_MODEL which will update the UI accordingly when set(Object) is called inside you view model.
    On the other hand, when the UI changes the property through the #set(From.View, object) method, all onChange(Channel, Action) with the channel From.VIEW listeners will be notified.
    Consider the following example property in your view model: 

    
 	    // A username property with a validation action:
 		private final Var<String> username = Var.of("").onChange(From.VIEW v -> validateUser(v) );
    And the following SwingTree example UI: 
    
 	    UI.textField("")
 	    .peek( tf -> vm.getUsername().onChange(From.VIEW_MODEL t -> tf.setText(t.get()) ) )
 	    .onKeyRelease( e -> vm.getUsername().set(From.VIEW, ta.getText() ) );
    Here your view will automatically update the item of the text property and inside your view model you can freely update the username property and it will automatically update the text field in the UI: 
    
 	    // Initially empty username:
 		username.set( "" ) // triggers 'fireChange(From.VIEW_MODEL)'

    If you no longer need to observe a property, you can use the Observable.unsubscribe(Subscriber) method to remove all Actions (which are also Subscribers) registered through onChange(Channel, Action).

    Note that the name of this class is short for "variable". This name was deliberately chosen because it is short, concise and yet clearly conveys the same meaning as other names used to model this kind of pattern, like "property", "observable object", "observable value", "observable property", etc. Using the names Var and Val also allows for the distinction between mutable and immutable properties without having to resort to prefixes like "mutable" or "immutable" as part of a type that is supposed to be used everywhere in your code.

    Please take a look at the living sprouts documentation where you can browse a large collection of examples demonstrating how to use the API of this class.

    • Method Detail

      • ofNullable

        static <T> Var<@Nullable T> ofNullable​(java.lang.Class<T> type,
                                       @Nullable T item)
        Use this factory method to create a new Var instance whose item may or may not be null.
        Var instances returned by this method will also report true for Val.allowsNull().

        Example: 

        
      Var.ofNullable(String.class, null);

        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the wrapped item.
        Parameters:
        type - The type of the item wrapped by the property. This is not only used to check if the item is of the correct type, but also so that the property knows its type, even if the item is null.
        item - The initial item of the property, which may be null.
        Returns:
        A new Var instance.

      • ofNull

        static <T> Var<@Nullable T> ofNull​(java.lang.Class<T> type)
        A more concise version of ofNullable(Class, Object) which is equivalent to Var.ofNullable(type, null).
        The Var instances returned by this factory method, are nullable, which means their Val.allowsNull() method will always yield true and they will not throw an IllegalArgumentException when set(Object) is called with a null item.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the wrapped item.
        Parameters:
        type - The type of the item wrapped by the property.
        Returns:
        A new Var instance.

      • of

        static <T> Var<T> of​(T item)
        This factory method returns a Var describing the given non-null item similar to Optional.of(Object), but specifically designed to be used for MVVM.
        Var instances returned by this method will report false for Val.allowsNull(), because the item is guaranteed to be non-null.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the item held by the Var!
        Parameters:
        item - The initial item of the property which must not be null.
        Returns:
        A new Var instance wrapping the given item.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the given item is null.

      • of

        static <T,​V extends T> Var<T> of​(java.lang.Class<T> type,
                                       V item)
        This factory method returns a Var describing the given non-null item similar to Optional.of(Object) and its type which may also be a super type of the supplied item.
        Var instances returned by this method will report false for Val.allowsNull(), because the item is guaranteed to be non-null.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the item held by the Var!
        V - The type of the item which is wrapped by the returned Var!
        Parameters:
        type - The type of the item wrapped by the property, or a super type of it.
        item - The initial item of the property which must not be null.
        Returns:
        A new Var instance wrapping the given item.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the given item is null.

      • set

        default Var<T> set​(T newItem)
        This method provides the ability to modify the state of the wrapper from the view model channel (see From.VIEW_MODEL). It might have several effects depending on the implementation.
        Parameters:
        newItem - The new item which ought to replace the old one.
        Returns:
        This very wrapper instance, in order to enable method chaining.

      • set

        Var<T> set​(Channel channel,
           T newItem)
        This method provides the ability to modify the state of the wrapper from a custom channel of your choice, usually one of the channels defined in From. It might have several effects depending on the implementation.
        Parameters:
        channel - The channel from which the item is set.
        newItem - The new item which ought to replace the old one.
        Returns:
        This very wrapper instance, in order to enable method chaining.

      • withId

        Var<T> withId​(java.lang.String id)
        Use this method to create a new property with an id. This id is used to identify the property in the UI or as a key in a map, which is useful when converting your view model to a JSON object, or similar formats.
        Specified by:
        withId in interface Val<T extends @Nullable java.lang.Object>
        Parameters:
        id - The id of the property.
        Returns:
        A new Var instance with the given id.

      • onChange

        Var<T> onChange​(Channel channel,
                Action<Val<T>> action)
        Use this to register an observer lambda for a particular Channel, which will be called whenever the item wrapped by this Val changes through the Var::set(Channel, T) method. The lambda will receive the current item of this property. The default channel is From.VIEW_MODEL, so if you use the Var::set(T) method then the observer lambdas registered through this method will be called.
        Specified by:
        onChange in interface Val<T extends @Nullable java.lang.Object>
        Parameters:
        channel - The channel from which the item is set.
        action - The lambda which will be called whenever the item wrapped by this Var changes.
        Returns:
        The Val instance itself.

      • map

        default Var<T> map​(java.util.function.Function<T,​T> mapper)
        If the item is present, then this applies the provided mapping function to it, and return it wrapped in a new Var instance.
        If the item is not present, then an empty Var instance is returned.

        But note that the resulting property does not constitute a live view of this property and will not be updated when this property changes.
        It is functionally very similar to the Optional.map(Function) method.

        If you want to map to a property which is an automatically updated live view of this property, then use the Val.view(Function) method instead. This is essentially the same as Optional.map(Function) but based on Var as the wrapper instead of Optional.

        Specified by:
        map in interface Val<T extends @Nullable java.lang.Object>
        Parameters:
        mapper - The mapping function to apply to an item, if present.
        Returns:
        A new property either empty (containing null) or containing the result of applying the mapping function to the item of this property.

      • mapTo

        default <U extends @Nullable java.lang.Object> Var<@Nullable U> mapTo​(java.lang.Class<U> type,
                                                                      java.util.function.Function<@NonNull T,​U> mapper)
        If the item is present, applies the provided mapping function to it, and returns it wrapped in a new Var instance.
        If the item is not present, then an empty Var instance is returned.

        But note that the resulting property does not constitute a live view of this property and will not be updated when this property changes.
        It is functionally very similar to the Optional.map(Function) method.

        If you want to map to a property which is an automatically updated live view of this property, then use the Val.viewAs(Class, Function) method instead.

        Specified by:
        mapTo in interface Val<T extends @Nullable java.lang.Object>
        Type Parameters:
        U - The type of the item returned from the mapping function
        Parameters:
        type - The type of the item returned from the mapping function
        mapper - the mapping function to apply to an item, if present
        Returns:
        A new property either empty (containing null) or containing the result of applying the mapping function to the item of this property.

      • zoomTo

        default <B> Var<B> zoomTo​(java.util.function.Function<T,​B> getter,
                          java.util.function.BiFunction<T,​B,​T> wither)
        Creates a lens property (Var) that focuses on a specific field of the current data structure. This method is used to zoom into an immutable nested data structure, allowing read and write operations on a specific field via getter and wither functions.

        For example, consider a record Author with fields firstName, lastName, birthDate, and books. Using zoomTo, you can create lenses for each field to access and update them individually. 

        
 var author = new Author("John", "Doe", LocalDate.of(1829, 8, 12), List.of("Book1", "Book2"));
 var authorProperty = Var.of(author);

 // Creating lenses for Author fields
 var firstNameLens = authorProperty.zoomTo(Author::getFirstName, Author::withFirstName);
 var lastNameLens = authorProperty.zoomTo(Author::getLastName, Author::withLastName);
 var birthDateLens = authorProperty.zoomTo(Author::getBirthDate, Author::withBirthDate);
 var booksLens = authorProperty.zoomTo(Author::getBooks, Author::withBooks);

 // Usage example: Update the first name via the lens
 firstNameLens.set("Jane");
        Type Parameters:
        B - The type of the field that the lens will focus on.
        Parameters:
        getter - Function to get the current value of the focused field from the parent object.
        wither - BiFunction to set or update the value of the focused field and return a new instance of the parent object with the updated field.
        Returns:
        A new Var that acts as a lens focusing on the specified field of the parent object.

      • zoomToNullable

        default <B extends @Nullable java.lang.Object> Var<B> zoomToNullable​(java.lang.Class<B> type,
                                                                     java.util.function.Function<T,​B> getter,
                                                                     java.util.function.BiFunction<T,​B,​T> wither)
        Creates a nullable lens property (Var) that focuses on a specific nullable field of the current data structure. This method is used to zoom into an immutable nested data structure, allowing read and write operations on a specific nullable field via getter and wither functions.

        For example, consider a record User with an optional email field. Using zoomToNullable, you can create a lens specifically for the email field, which is optional and can be null. 

        
 var user = new User("sam42", MembershipLevel.GOLD, LocalDate.of(2020, 1, 1), "sam.sus@example.com");
 var userProperty = Var.of(user);

 // Creating a lens for the nullable email field
 var emailLens = userProperty.zoomToNullable(String.class, User::email, User::withEmail);

 // Usage example: Update the email via the lens
 emailLens.set(null);
        Type Parameters:
        B - The type of the nullable field that the lens will focus on.
        Parameters:
        type - The class type of the nullable field.
        getter - Function to get the current value of the focused nullable field from the parent object.
        wither - BiFunction to set or update the value of the focused nullable field and return a new instance of the parent object with the updated field.
        Returns:
        A new Var that acts as a lens focusing on the specified nullable field of the parent object.
